text: This is Daniel Friedman, and I am very pleased to be introducing our speaker, Andy Lomas.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Andy Lomas is a computational artist, mathematician and Emmy Award winning supervisor of computer generated effects.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: His artwork explores how complex structural forms can be created emergently by simulating growth processes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So certainly at the intersection of art and science.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Currently, he is based in London.

text: And basically, every simulation starts with a ball of 42 cells.

text: And then there are rules for how cells divide.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: where we start reading things in it, but instead of just being almost looking just like a ball of chemical cells, it starts reading as something of a quite maybe ornate organic complexity.

text: And then from those, I'm seeing ones that look like they might have some potential to be interesting.

text: And, you know, so basically I'm sort of rating and categorizing the sort of like things at the seedling level.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's saying that each cell is directly linked to a small number of other cells sort of like immediately around it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Then we have rules for cell division, so that basically after a cell has got enough food, the food level exceeds a certain threshold, then that cell is selected to be divided into two cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we do this by choosing a plane of cleavage, so almost like choosing two edges, which is where the split is going to happen.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and then deleting all the edges to one side of that edge, creating a daughter cell, I guess pushing the parents and the daughter cell a little bit away from each other, and then reconnecting the daughter cell back into the mesh.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So basically what we end up with is, we start with a mesh of triangles, what we end up with is still a mesh of triangles, but now with an additional cell added into the structure.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and has hopefully you can sort of see it's like it's an incredibly simplified version of uh sort of a biology and it's sort of like it's really plain you know i'm amazingly simplified you know instead of all the things on biology like you know cells then different types of cells being created and cells walking off into and finding where they should locate themselves and things like that this is like saying it's astonishingly simple model that's going to say one thing i'm not interested in is how simple could the model
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: but yet hopefully still create surprisingly sort of rich results.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So then the other thing I have in here is that I see a set of influences as the other cells around it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So firstly, just like a set of almost like spring forces so that each cell tries to maintain a rest distance from the other cells that it's directly connected to.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if the cells are too close to each other, they sort of push themselves apart.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If they're further apart than the rest distance, they'll try to pull each other, pull back towards each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Then the next thing I've got is another sort of two influences, which basically almost like try to make the surface either bulge or sort of smooth out.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I guess this is sort of informed, I guess I come from a computer graphics sort of background.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this is informed by, there's quite a lot of work back in the 90s
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: he's on cloth simulations and what they found was that if you just have straight stem source springs in the stress in a mesh what you end up with is a limited set of things it basically almost only acts like stiff rubber come chain mail if you want to get more rich sort of like you know folding
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: what you need to do is almost like things that actively make the surface fold or try to keep itself smooth.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is trying to be informed by that, by having firstly an influence where if the cells are closer to each other than rest distance, so that basically the sheet is in compression,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: then the cells deliberately try to bulge outwards.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So basically what we do is we calculate, we have normals to the surface, almost like vectors pointing straight out from the surface.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what we do is work out where would the cell have to move to in order to get back to rest distance if it was having to slide along the normal.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we work that out for all the cells around and just almost like a bit of an average.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that's almost like something that the cell tries to move towards that sort of bulging position.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then secondly, it's almost like a thing that's going the opposite direction.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It basically just says if the cell tries to move back towards the average of the cells connected around it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's an influence that tends to smooth things back out.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if you just think about it, these are almost like working against each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that's the sort of thing I'm often interested in, is almost like ingredients in these sorts of systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And there'd be different weights for almost like how smoothing sort of influence.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you can almost imagine that if I had a system set up with a bold influence being really strong and a planar one being really weak, what you might have is a sys setup where it almost wants to wrinkle and fold like that.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Whereas if the planar smoothing influence was much stronger, maybe this system would want to keep itself much flatter so that you end up with things maybe more like sort of bubbles and sort of balloon-like sort of structures.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's almost like by hopefully just trying to get a good interesting mix of ingredients that are going to have a number of different behaviors.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then the final influence I've got in here is what of course is a repulsion influence.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is almost like a really small, almost like electrostatic repulsion between the cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what I'm showing here, hopefully you can see the animation over the link, is basically two simulations, but with exactly the same parameters for all the influences, apart from the one on the left.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: we've got this almost like electrostatic repulsion, whereas on the right, there isn't any.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is basically the idea is as the cells fold in 3D space and come close to each other, so cells which are distant in the sheet, but in 3D space come close to each other, they just have a small repulsion, a bit like static electricity pushing the cells apart.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And with that, what we end up with is potentially much more rich, interesting structures.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: but you know often really filigree branch like tendril like horizontal like the sort of structures coming out of the forms so i guess it's almost like a cautionary tale almost like don't try to outguess complex systems or you know they they will they often produce really incredibly rich behavior but if you're trying to direct them they will often go in a completely unexpected direction but i think the
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: programming, creating these sorts of branch-like structures, I think would actually be really quite difficult.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I think what's interesting is this is genuinely emergent.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I really was not intending to make these types of forms, structures from this code, but almost the system was rich enough that it just happened, you know, emergently.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: um and the reason that i sort of looked into it it's like okay what's happening um it was basically it was first of all a bug in my code that i guess i'm creating you know food in cells based on this sort of simulated photosynthesis and light rays coming in hitting cells
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But one thing I was doing was because I've got these cells between two sheets and then I'm growing more and more and more cells, I was deliberately shrinking the cells, shrinking the rest length as the sheet grew.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But I was forgetting to do that sort of change of shrinking the size of the cells as far as the photosynthesis code.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I hadn't sort of put that into that bit of the code.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So as far as the photosynthesis, the light rays were concerned, all these cells were huge.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So these big cells, one cell sticks out a little bit further than its neighbours, it tends to shadow all its neighbours and grabs all the food.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So anything that sticks out a little bit becomes the focus where all the food happens.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then the second thing was how I'd implemented these varying growth rates, things like the overhang angle,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I hadn't thought through properly.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What I tried doing was, I guess, trying to be a bit too clever.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's always dangerous trying to be a bit too clever.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I sort of thought, OK, simple way to do that is I could just change the rate of time.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It was like I can slow down growth by making time go slower in some parts of the structure than in other.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That's a fun, cute idea.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: bad idea.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Basically what that was doing was effectively freezing the structure when it got beyond certain overhang angles.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So essentially what I've done is come up with a recipe to cause growth where anything that sticks out a little bit further from the surface than other things nearby
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if anything goes beyond an overhang angle, it becomes solidified, it becomes a permanent structure.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So essentially it's a recipe to create, accidental recipe to create these like branch-like forms.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's useless to make actually fabricated sculptures, but I think really interesting in its own right.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it almost becomes an accidental artwork series.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: tree sculptures.

text: So this is actually an exhibition from actually the Victoria and Albert Museum in London invited me to have an exhibit as part of the London Design Festival.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is like an exhibit with some sculptures and also I guess it was almost like developmental series of small maquettes and sculptures showing them going from their original tube-like structure to the final sort of vase, basically going from about 300 cells to start with to about 10 or 20 million cells by the end.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and also you know animations showing the structures grow sort of growing so i hope you see i'm i am actually be able to make these forms actually as surreal sculptures so now i'm going to sort of like switch into maybe almost like talking a bit more about the process and the back story behind this because these exist systems so both
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Basically, it's the problem of like, you know, okay, now, when I've got a system like this, how do I find interesting behavior?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: How do I find things which I think is particularly rich and things that, you know, I look at and think, you know, there's something of aesthetic quality or something that a reason that I react to that form, but don't react to that form.

text: And I guess one intuition I've got is that it's often almost transition points in the behaviors, the space of behaviors that you're always looking for.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You're looking for not so much typical behavior, but the sort of interesting atypical behavior that often happens at transition points.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is actually a plot from a work from quite a few years ago called the aggregation series, which basically is a plot of changing parameter values.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So in this series, I just had a small number, two or three parameter values, almost changing the environment that things were growing in, basically using a very, or even simpler form of growth, what's called diffusion limited aggregation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is basically where along the horizontal axis, I'm changing one parameter of the environment, along the vertical axis, changing a different parameter.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I guess what you get from this is you get to the far right-hand side, the system's becoming unstable.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's getting to the point where the forces in the environment are so strong that it's almost shredding the structures.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And in this, it's almost the tipping point as you get into that instability, almost in the sort of sixth and seventh columns, where you start to see, I think, some, you know, interesting, rich, unexpected sort of structures, which, you know, the pensioner, you know, okay, that's something that has some artistic qualities to it.

text: So it's almost like, how do you then sort of find transition barriers?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Maybe those sort of transitions to instability.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It might be, I guess, in chaotic systems, almost like transition point between regularity and chaos, the border as you get into chaos, like the edge of the Mandelbrot set where potentially interesting behavior happens.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So one thing I've been writing over quite a lot, actually over the last 10 years, is writing a piece of software called Speech Explorer, which is basically just an interface for me to use to try to explore the parameter space and the possibilities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So basically, what I can use is this software, it sets off, chooses parameters to try new samples to generate forms at, sets off the generation engine, and then gets back the images from the generation engine once it's generated a form, and then I can look at that in the user interface, and I can do things like I can give them scores.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I can say, well, that one just failed.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The simulation didn't run.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We'll give that a zero.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That it ran, but it was really rubbish.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Let's give it a one out of 10.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That's a bit more interesting, maybe a three or four out of 10, or that's really quite interesting, maybe about six or seven.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So basically just giving it subjectively a score of what I think almost like aesthetic value.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But I can also give scores for other things, like how many tendrils something's got.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Or I can put things into categories.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I can say that those things all remind me of furry structures.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Those are all brain-like things.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Those are broccoli.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Those are sea creatures.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I can give things almost like names and categories, which is hopefully then useful data to almost like help navigate the parameter space.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then I can use almost like a number of different methods to then set off generating another next population, that set of individuals.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I can maybe just generate individuals with random parameters, which potentially, particularly when you're starting with a new system, I've got no idea what parameter values, I've only put together a set of interesting ingredients, but I've no idea what parameter values may work.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Let's just try things randomly.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And once I've seen a few things, maybe I could start using evolutionary methods.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So particularly if I've found a form I really quite like, just maybe creating some mutants around it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So close in the space around that individual, randomly mutate the parameter values and generate another one.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Or crossbreed that individual with another one.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So almost like taking a leaf out of evolutionary methods.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The other thing I've also been using is very quite simple machine learning.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's basically a system what's called k-nearest neighbors, which is like a ridiculously simple form of machine learning where you just estimate values or categories based on what is the value of the nearest neighbors in the parameter space.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's almost like I will estimate the score at a new point in the parameter space as being what are the scores of other things that I've already sampled nearby.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So ridiculously simple form of machine learning, which hopefully gives me some level of prediction of new points in the parameter space, as long as I haven't got too many parameters.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so I've been using this as a number of different techniques in here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Now, more recently, I guess one of the stories in artificial intelligence is deep neural networks have become the thing.

text: So I guess one question is then, well, can we start using deep neural networks to almost take these ideas even further?

text: So what we've been working with is actually main data from the original cellular forms, where basically we've got about just over 1,700 cellular forms, which I basically, from the original work, have rated and categorized all the forms into categories like animal and balloon and brain and plant.

text: And these all have like 12 parameters in their sort of genotype.

text: So that's basically the data set.

text: So it's actually on GitHub open source.

text: And so what we've been doing this, well, firstly, one thing is, well, can just, can it automatically categorize things?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So using techniques, the things that were called variational autoencoders and TSNE, can this kind of deep neural net almost automatically without new training from me, start to categorize things in a way which seems to roughly match maybe the sorts of categories and divisions that I'm making.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and what we're finding is in genotype space it really doesn't that we are genotype space at least all the techniques we're trying so far are effectively dimensional reduction methods based on the deep neural net data um or general net produces a vector which is then dimensionally reduced
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: it really seems to almost always just be a bit of a mess.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But on the phenotype space, when it's actually looking at the images, we do seem to be getting things that seem to make structural sense.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And almost this potentially could be tools to help, almost be more suggestions for how to divide the forms into different categories.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Maybe almost like finer subdivisions, maybe that I've made, almost like interesting subcategories to make.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So based on the lower plot there, you have been seeing that, you know, the categories that I put things into seem to almost like match reasonably nicely with what this, which is using TSME to do dimensional reduction, seems to produce like quite sort of, you know, interestingly structural meaningful results.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then looking at like, can it sort of like score things and rate things, you know, sort of similar to me based on both the image data and the phenotype and the parameter values, the sort of genotype.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we're using here is actually two different types of neural nets.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So firstly, from the image data, we're using ResNet-50, which is a reasonably state of the art convolutional neural network used to classify images or classify and rank images.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: so basically this is a neural net that's been uh or pre-trained on over a million images from the image net database so guess it's almost been already trained how to see and then what we can do is just train the last few layers of the network to say you know okay what we want you to do is rating and categorizing our sort of cellular forms data
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the second thing is using what's called a fully connected deep neural net.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's where you've got a certain number of hidden layers.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So basically we can set our own inputs, which would be the parameter values and the genotype, outputs being the scores and categories we're interested in, and then a small number of layers and neurons between the two as a way of hopefully getting predictions based on the genotype space.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what we're finding is it has worked.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So basically, compared with k-nearest neighbors, where we were getting basically at best about a 50% prediction accuracy, there are things like ResNet-50 looking at the image data is getting about an 87% prediction accuracy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And a fully connected deep neural network on the genotype parameter is getting just under about 70%.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So deep neural nets seem to be already doing better significantly than we were getting with k-nearest neighbors.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's useful.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then what we're looking at is integrating this into Species Explorer in a sort of number of different ways, almost to help to be tools to help explore the space.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02
